CHAPTER 761
Taxicabs
761.01   Definition.
761.02   Taxicab License Board; licensing; renewal.
761.03   License required; fees.
761.04   Insurance requirements.
761.05   Commercial driver registration and photograph; bond.
761.06   Soliciting fares along bus routes prohibited.
761.07   Vehicle capacity limits.
761.08   Overloading vehicle unlawful; exception.
761.09   Refusal to pay fare.
761.10   Vehicle license numbers; painting on taxicabs.
761.11   Revocation of license.
761.12   Licensee to pay expenses of photographs.
761.13   Provisions not applicable to bus company.
761.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.22, 715.66
   Power to establish stands and fix rates - see Ohio R.C. 715.25
   Chauffeur's license not required - see Ohio R.C. 4501.01
   Operation by minor prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 4507.321
   Operation and equipment - see TRAF. CODE
   Defrauding a livery - see GEN. OFF.
545.13
761.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purposes of this chapter, "taxicab" means any motor vehicle whose
owner or driver solicits, secures or accepts passengers for hire on hail or
request on the public streets in the City. "Taxicab" does not include a vehicle
such as a bus or other vehicle furnishing transportation to the public on a
fixed schedule or route.
(1979 Code 113.01)
761.02 TAXICAB LICENSE BOARD; LICENSING; RENEWAL.
   (a)   For the purpose of determining the public convenience and necessity
for the issuing of taxicab licenses, there is hereby created a Taxicab License
Board, consisting of the Director of Public Service-Safety, the Chief of Police
and the Mayor.
(1979 Code 34.45)
   (b)   The Taxicab License Board shall investigate and hold a hearing for
each application for license for each taxicab, and if the Board finds from such
investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity justify the
operation of the vehicle for which the license is desired, it shall notify the
applicant of its findings, and the applicant, within thirty days thereafter,
shall proceed to comply with the terms of this chapter.
   (c)   If the Board finds from such investigation and hearing that the public
convenience and necessity do not justify the operating of such vehicle for
which the license is desired, it shall notify the applicant of its findings.
All decisions of the Board shall be final.
   (d)   All taxicabs licensed in accordance with the terms of this chapter, or
which are licensed at the time the amendment is adopted, shall have their
licenses renewed for each successive year without a finding of convenience and
necessity by the Board, provided all other requirements of this chapter are
complied with. All licensees shall be notified of each hearing, and shall have
the right to file objections in writing to the issuance of additional licenses.
(1979 Code 113.02)
761.03 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEES.
   No person, association of persons, firm or corporation shall carry on or
engage in the business of operating taxicabs or automobiles or other vehicles
for the transportation of persons, for hire, on and over the streets, avenues
and other public places in the City until such person, association of persons,
firm or corporation has obtained a license to do so. The license issued shall
be effective for one year, and shall be issued by the Mayor on the payment of
five dollars ($5.00) for each vehicle, up to and including five vehicles, and
three dollars ($3.00) for each additional vehicle so operated for each year or
part thereof. Each license shall be in force and effect until January 1
following the date of issuance.
(1979 Code 113.03)
761.04 INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   No person shall engage in the business of operating taxicabs, automobiles
and other vehicles, or shall operate such taxicabs, automobiles or other
vehicles for the transportation of persons for hire within the City, or shall
permit such to be operated, until the applicant for a license hereunder
deposits with the Mayor a policy or certificate of liability insurance for
insuring each vehicle for which a license is applied for. The insurance shall
be acceptable to the City Director of Law, indemnifying the applicant in the
sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) for injury to one person and twenty-five
thousand dollars ($25,000) for injury to more than one person and two thousand
five hundred dollars ($2,500) for property damage, in any one accident through
the operation of such vehicle, together with a clause requiring the surety or
insurance company to give ten days' written notice to the Mayor before
cancellation, expiration or termination of such policy of insurance.
(1979 Code 113.04)
761.05 COMMERCIAL DRIVER REGISTRATION AND PHOTOGRAPH; BOND.
   (a)   No commercial driver shall operate such taxicab, automobile or other
vehicle until he has registered his name and address, and has deposited with
the Mayor his photograph of the size required for a commercial driver's
license, a complete set of fingerprints made and certified by the Chief of
Police or the fingerprint officer of the Police Department, and a bond in the
amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) conditioned on such operator complying
with the terms of this chapter and conducting himself and operating the cab in
a lawful and satisfactory manner.
   (b)   No commercial driver for a non-profit company or organization shall
operate such taxicab, automobile or other vehicle until he has registered his
name and address, and has deposited with the Mayor his photograph of the size
required for a commercial driver's license, a complete set of fingerprints made
and certified by the Chief of Police or the fingerprint officer of the Police
Department, and a bond in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
conditioned on such operator complying with the terms of this chapter and
conducting himself and operating the cab in a lawful and satisfactory manner.
The bond fee stated herein shall be in effect as long as the service being
provided is not a same day program.
(Ord. 1999-12. Passed 1-19-99.)
761.06 SOLICITING FARES ALONG BUS ROUTES PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No operator of any vehicle engaged in the business of transportation
of persons for hire on and over the streets, avenues and other public places in
the City shall orally solicit patronage, or cruise for the purpose and
intention of making such solicitation by such operator, or shall take up and
accept as a result of oral solicitation a person or persons for transportation
for hire on or along North and South Main Street or any other street or route
over which the bus franchise holder operates and maintains a regular schedule
in compliance with and by virtue of the franchise heretofore entered into
between such bus franchise holder and the City.
   (b)   "Cruise" means to drive at a slow rate of speed with the intended
purpose of soliciting, receiving and accepting the person or persons for
transportation for hire.
(1979 Code 113.06)
761.07 VEHICLE CAPACITY LIMITS.
   The capacity of such vehicle shall be the number of passengers, including
the operator, that is listed as the passenger limitation by the manufacturer of
the vehicle.
(1979 Code 113.08)
761.08 OVERLOADING VEHICLE UNLAWFUL; EXCEPTION.
   No operator shall receive passengers in a vehicle beyond its capacity
without the request and consent of each and every occupant at that time
occupying the vehicle.
(1979 Code 113.09)
761.09 REFUSAL TO PAY FARE.
   No person or persons shall ride as a fare or fares in any licensed vehicle
without paying the regular and customary charge for such transportation. The
refusal to pay such fare or fares shall be subject to the fine hereinafter
provided.
(1979 Code 113.10)
761.10 VEHICLE LICENSE NUMBERS; PAINTING ON TAXICABS.
   Each vehicle licensed hereunder shall have a number assigned to it by the
Mayor. This number shall appear in the license, and shall be fastened or
suspended on the back of the front seat of each respective vehicle in a
position easily visible to any passenger. The figures of the number shall be at
least two inches in height. The same number shall be painted on each side and
on the rear of the vehicle in a color in contrast to the color of the body of
the vehicle in a permanent manner by painting or other like method in such a
manner as not to become dim. The number shall be kept clean and in such
condition to remain visible and in such location as to be plainly visible to a
person at a distance of fifty feet, and shall be at least six inches in height.
(1979 Code 113.11)
761.11 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Mayor is authorized and empowered to revoke the license of any person,
partnership or corporation issued in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter, whenever such person, partnership or corporation, or any agent or
employee thereof, has been convicted or has pleaded guilty to the violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter, or any of the other provisions of this
Code, or when by reason of incompetency, negligence or gross misconduct, the
Mayor is of the opinion that in the interest of the public the same should be
revoked.
(1979 Code 113.12)
761.12 LICENSEE TO PAY EXPENSES OF PHOTOGRAPHS.
   The photograph and the card or device on which the number of the license is
carried in the vehicle and the expense of painting the numbers on the vehicle
shall be furnished or paid for by the licensee, and is not included in the fee
charged for the license.
(1979 Code 113.13)
761.13 PROVISIONS NOT APPLICABLE TO BUS COMPANY.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the bus franchise holder,
its successor or assigns, during the period of the holder's franchise, or such
term for which it may be renewed or extended.
(1979 Code 113.14)
761.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter, for which another penalty
is not already provided, shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars
($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day's violation
shall constitute a separate offense.
(1979 Code 113.99)
CHAPTER 767
Mobile Food Units, Solicitors, Peddlers and Itinerant Merchants
767.01   Sale of goods on street; license.
767.02   Definitions.
767.03   License required.
767.04   Exceptions.
767.05   Mobile food units.
767.06   Solicitors, peddlers and itinerant merchants.
767.07   Appeals.
767.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
      Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
      Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
      Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
      Door to door sales activity of minors restricted - see
         Ohio R.C. 4109.21
767.01 SALE OF GOODS ON STREET; LICENSE.
      (a)    No person shall sell any goods, merchandise or medicines on Main
Street in the City, between Lima and Center Streets, or on any streets or
alleys connecting with Main Street between Lima and Center Streets, or within
400 feet of Main Street. Goods, merchandise and medicines may be sold at other
places in the City when the seller has obtained a license to do so issued by
the Mayor.
      (b)    Subsection (a) hereof shall not apply to local merchants and
businesses that have a fixed place of business located within the defined area
as described herein and they shall be permitted to transact business within
such area on the streets or alleys provided, however, that the conduct of
business is on a temporary basis with no fixed or permanent structures or
fixtures and that at the close of business each day the street or alley is
restored to its original condition.
(Ord. 2024-146. Passed 1-7-25.)
767.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.
      (a)    "Goods" or "wares" means any item of personal property including,
but not limited to, merchandise, appliances, magazines, magazine subscriptions,
books, photographs, produce, food items, but excluding newspapers and products
or articles raised or manufactured by such person.
   (b)    "Mobile Food Unit" or food truck means any apparatus or equipment
that is used to cook, prepare or serve food, and that routinely changes or can
change location and is operated from a moveable vehicle or apparatus, including
but not limited to motorized vehicles, trailers, and hand propelled carts.
   (c)    "Solicitor" or "canvasser" means a person with no fixed place of
business in the City dealing primarily with consumers, who takes orders for
goods for future delivery or for personal services to be furnished in the
future, whether by telephone or by house-to-house or business-to-business
canvassing.
   (d)    "Itinerant merchant" or "vendor" means a person with a fixed place of
business in the City, but who has been located in this City for a period of
less than one year, or who has not maintained a voting residence in this City
for more than one year, and who offers for sale goods or wares.
   (e)   "Peddler" means any person with no fixed place of business in the
City, who carries wares or goods with him which he is prepared to sell at the
time he solicits business, and who deals primarily with consumers. "Peddler"
includes "hawker" and "huckster."
            (Ord. 2024-146. Passed 1-7-25.)
767.03 LICENSE REQUIRED.
      No person shall engage in the business of mobile food unit, solicitor,
peddler, canvasser or itinerant merchant, as defined in Section
767.02, and no person shall solicit sales of, sell, offer for sale, barter or
exchange goods, wares or personal services without obtaining a license.
(Ord. 2024-146. Passed 1-7-25.)
767.04 EXCEPTIONS.
      The requirements of a license as provided herein shall not apply to a
duly authorized solicitor soliciting the sale of goods or wares for or on
behalf of any recognized educational, civic, religious or charitable
organization.
(Ord. 2024-146. Passed 1-7-25.)
767.05 MOBILE FOOD UNITS.
      (a)    A mobile food unit license is required for the sale of food by a
mobile food unit on public or private property selling to the general public.
Applications for mobile food units as defined in this chapter shall be filed
with the Mayor on a form to be furnished by the Mayor. The application shall
contain the following information:
      (1)    Name of applicant.
      (2)    Name of mobile food unit.
      (3)    Address of mobile food unit.
      (4)    Social Security Number or Employer Identification Number.
     (b)    The applicant shall further furnish the following:
      (1)    Copy of driver's license or state issued identification card.
      (2)    Copy of State of Ohio, Department of Health food service permit.
      (3)    Copy of Findlay Fire Department inspection.
      (4)    Copy of propane pressure tank leak test report, performed by a
licensed, bonded professional in accordance with National Fire Protection
Association (NFPA) and Ohio Fire Code (OFC) standards, if applicable.
      (5)    Proof of current liability insurance of a minimum of one million
dollars ($1,000,000).
      (6)    Proof of registration with Findlay City Income Tax.
    (c)    For the purpose of this chapter and the license to be issued
hereunder, each applicant for license for mobile food unit, as defined in this
chapter shall pay to the City the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). All
licenses issued hereunder shall be for a period of one year which shall end on
December 31 of that calendar year in which they are acquired, regardless of the
date such license is acquired.
     (d)    The license issued hereunder shall be exhibited in the mobile food
unit, and shall be carried by mobile food unit at all times when operating, and
shall be exhibited to any person or any police officer on request. Further, a
sticker shall be issued to the licensed mobile food unit that shall be
displayed on the mobile food unit at or near the location that orders are
taken.
     (e)    No mobile food unit as defined in Section
767.02 shall operate within 100 feet of an existing restaurant unless
permission has been obtained by the restaurant owner.
(Ord. 2024-146. Passed 1-7-25.)
767.06 SOLICITORS, PEDDLERS, AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS
   (a)    Applications for licenses for peddlers, solicitors and itinerant
merchants, as defined in this chapter shall be filed with the Mayor on a form
to be furnished by the Mayor. The forms shall contain the following
information:
      (1)    Name of applicant.
      (2)    Home address.
      (3)    Name and address of the person by whom employed.
      (4)    Length of service with such employer.
      (5)    All places of residence and all employment during the preceding
year.
      (6)    The nature and character of the goods to be sold or service to be
furnished by the applicant.
      (7)    Names of other towns in which the applicant has recently conducted
a business for which a license is herein required.
      (8)    A personal description and history of the applicant.
   (b)   The applicant shall further furnish a copy of their driver's license
or Federal ID. The applicant shall obtain a BCI&I background check including
fingerprinting through an agency authorized to perform same. Results of the
BCI&I background check and fingerprinting shall be submitted to the Mayor in
order to enable the Mayor to investigate the moral character and record of the
applicant.
      (c)    If the Mayor determines after an investigation that the applicant
is of good moral character and proposes to engage in a lawful commercial or
professional enterprise, a license shall be issued which shall expire on
December 31 of the year in which the license is issued.
    (d)   For the purpose of this chapter and the license to be issued
hereunder, each applicant for licenses for solicitors, peddlers and itinerant
merchants, as defined in this chapter shall pay to the City the sum of five
dollars ($5.00). All licenses issued hereunder shall be for a period of one
year which shall end on December 31 of that calendar year in which they are
acquired, regardless of the date such license is acquired.
     (e)    The license issued hereunder shall be exhibited in the place of
business by itinerant merchants, and shall be carried by any solicitor or
peddler at all times when soliciting or peddling, and shall be exhibited to any
person solicited or any police officer on request. In the case of solicitors or
peddlers, an identification badge shall be issued which shall be worn while
engaging in business. (Ord. 2024-146. Passed 1-7-25.)
767.07 APPEALS.
      Any applicant who has applied for a license in accordance with this
chapter and to whom the Mayor has, after investigation, denied a license, shall
be entitled to appeal to Council. Notice of such appeal shall be filed with the
Clerk of Council within five days after denial of the license by the Mayor.
Council, on appeal, may grant or reject the application for a license.
(Ord. 2024-146. Passed 1-7-25.)
767.99 PENALTY.
      Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor
of the fourth degree. Each day's continued violation shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Ord. 2024-146. Passed 1-7-25.)
CHAPTER 769
Video Service Providers
769.01   Fee established.
 
769.01 FEE ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   Council hereby establishes a VSP Fee that is calculated by applying a
VSP fee percentage of three percent (3%) to a video service provider’s gross
revenues as defined in Section 1332.32(B) of the Video Law. All video service
providers and cable television operators providing video service in the City
shall apply the VSP fee percentage against gross revenues as defined in the
Video Law.
   (b)   The VSP fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the City on a quarterly basis but not sooner than forty-five days
nor later than sixty days after the end of each calendar quarter. (ORC 1332.32
(A))
   (c)   The Mayor is authorized and directed to provide any video service
provider with notice of the VSP fee percentage as determined by this Council
above, which notice shall be given by certified mail, upon receipt of notice
from such video service provider that it will begin providing video service in
the City pursuant to a State-issued video service authorization.
(Ord. 2009-072. Passed 7-21-09.)
CHAPTER 773
Outdoor Public Entertainment Activity
773.01   Definitions.
773.02   Registration required by sponsoring agency and operator.
773.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.48, 715.63, 3765.02
      State licensing of portable amusement devices - see Ohio R.C. 1711.11(H)
      County license for public shows - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3765
773.01 DEFINITIONS.
   Unless otherwise expressly stated in this chapter, the following terms shall
have the meanings provided in this section.
   (a)   "Operator" means the person, firm, partnership, corporation, club,
society or other legal entity that operates or supervises any outdoor public
entertainment activity or constructs structures incident to outdoor public
entertainment.
   (b)   "Outdoor public entertainment" means any carnival, fair, festival or
similar enterprise which offers to the public, for a fee, any one or
combination of: amusement rides; games of chance for which prizes may be
awarded; sales of food or beverages; exposition of or offer for sale of goods;
entertainment performance or series of performances; or musical concert.
   (c)   "Sponsoring agency" means the person, firm, partnership, corporation,
club, society or other legal entity that organizes, funds, promotes or sponsors
any outdoor public entertainment.
773.02 REGISTRATION REQUIRED BY SPONSORING AGENCY AND OPERATOR.
   (a)   No sponsoring agency shall conduct or operate or allow to be conducted
or operated any outdoor public entertainment within the City without prior
approved registration with the Director of Public Safety and Service.
   (b)   No operator shall operate any form of outdoor public entertainment
without prior approved registration with the Director of Public Safety and
Service.
   (c)   Such registration will be completed to the satisfaction of the
Director of Public Safety and Service on forms prescribed by such Director.
773.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree. Each day constitutes a separate violation.
                                                                                                                            
CHAPTER 777
Panhandling
777.01   Definitions.
777.02   Time of panhandling.
777.03   Place of panhandling.
777.04   Manner of panhandling.
777.05   False or misleading solicitation.
777.06   Causing a minor to panhandle.
777.07   Registration.
777.99   Penalty.
777.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   Panhandling, for the purpose of this chapter, shall mean to beg, ask,
or solicit personal financial assistance to obtain an immediate donation of
money or other item having value. Purchase of an item for an amount far
exceeding its value, under circumstances where a reasonable person would
understand that the purchase is in substance a donation, is a donation for the
purpose of this chapter. Panhandling does not include passively standing or
sitting with a sign or other indication that one is seeking donations, without
addressing any solicitation to any specific person other than in response to an
inquiry by that person.
   (b)   The central area of the City shall mean the Central Business District
as set forth in Findlay's Zoning Code and map appended thereto.
(Ord. 2006-066. Passed 9-19-06.)
777.02 TIME OF PANHANDLING.
   No person shall panhandle after sunset or before sunrise. The times of
sunset and of sunrise shall be as published by the United States Naval
Observatory.
(Ord. 2006-066. Passed 9-19-06.)
777.03 PLACE OF PANHANDLING.
No person shall panhandle by soliciting a person in any of the following
places:
   (a)   At any bus stop;
   (b)   In any public transportation vehicle or facility;
   (c)   In any vehicle within the public right-of-way;
   (d)   Within twenty feet (20') of any entrance or exit of any bank, savings
and loan association, credit union, or check cashing business during its
business hours or within twenty feet (20') of any automated teller machine
during the time it is available for customers' use;
   (e)   In or at any hall or theater owned or operated by a political
subdivision;
   (f)   On private property, unless the panhandler has permission from the
owner or occupant.
(Ord. 2006-066. Passed 9-19-06.)
777.04 MANNER OF PANHANDLING.
   No person shall panhandle in any of the following manners:
   (a)   By coming within three feet (3') of the person solicited after that
person has indicated that he/she does not wish to make a donation;
   (b)   By blocking the path of a person who attempts to walk or drive away
from the panhandler;
   (c)   By following a person who walks away from the panhandler;
   (d)   By making unreasonable noise or offensively coarse utterance, gesture,
or display or communicating unwarranted and grossly abusive language, either
during the solicitation or following a refusal;
   (e)   By panhandling in a group of two or more persons; or
   (f)   By any statement, gesture, or other communication which a reasonable
person in the situation of the person solicited would perceive to be a threat.
      (Ord. 2006-066. Passed 9-19-06.)
777.05 FALSE OR MISLEADING SOLICITATION.
   No person shall knowingly make a false or misleading representation in the
course of soliciting a donation. False or misleading representations include,
but are not limited to, the following:
   (a)   Stating that the donation is needed to meet a specific need, when the
solicitor already has sufficient funds to meet that need and does not disclose
that fact;
   (b)   Stating that the donation is needed to meet a need which does not
exist;
   (c)   Stating that the solicitor is from out of town and stranded, when that
is not true;
   (d)   Wearing a military uniform or other indication of military service,
when the solicitor is neither a present nor former member of the service
indicated;
   (e)   Wearing or displaying an indication of physical disability, when the
solicitor does not suffer the disability indicated;
   (f)   Using any makeup or device to simulate any deformity;
   (g)   Stating that the solicitor is homeless, when he/she is not.
      (Ord. 2006-066. Passed 9-19-06.)
777.06 CAUSING A MINOR TO PANHANDLE.
   No parent, guardian, or adult person having legal care, control, or custody
of a minor shall cause, allow, or procure such minor to panhandle in or upon
any public or private property.
(Ord. 2006-066. Passed 9-19-06.)
777.07 REGISTRATION.
   (a)   No person shall panhandle or seek personal donations in a public
right-of-way without a registration issued by the Chief of Police or designee.
The registration shall include the name and photograph of the person to whom it
is issued. Any person who has been registered shall display the registration in
plain view on the front of that person at all times while panhandling or
seeking personal donations in a public right-of-way. No person whose
registration has been revoked shall panhandle or seek personal donations in a
public right-of-way for a period of two (2) years following the revocation.
   (b)   The Chief of Police shall issue the registration, without fee, to any
eligible person who presents himself/herself at the City of Findlay Municipal
Building, states his/her true name, presents a photo identification, or signs a
declaration under penalty of perjury that he/she has no such identification,
and permits himself/herself to be photographed and fingerprinted.
   (c)   A person is ineligible to register if, and only if, within the past
five (5) years he/she:
      (1)    Has pleaded guilty to or been convicted of two (2) or more
violations of registration;
      (2)    Has had a registration revoked pursuant to subsection (f) below;
or
      (3)    Has pleaded guilty to or been convicted of two (2) or more
offenses under the laws of any jurisdiction which involve aggressive or
intimidating behavior while panhandling or false or misleading representations
while panhandling.
   (d)   Upon receipt of an application for registration in accordance with
subsection (b) above, the Chief of Police shall issue a temporary registration
valid for ten (10) days and shall determine eligibility for a regular
registration before the temporary registration expires. An eligible applicant
shall receive a regular registration upon determination of the applicant's
eligibility. The regular registration shall expire one (1) year from the date
of issuance. Along with the registration, the Chief of Police shall give the
applicant a copy of this section.
   (e)   No person shall make a false or misleading representation while
applying for registration under this section.
   (f)   Upon arrest for any violation of the above said regulations, a
panhandler shall release to the arresting officer any registration issued under
this section to the arrestee. The arrestee may apply to the Chief of Police for
consecutive thirty (30) day temporary registrations pending adjudication of the
arrest case. The Chief of Police shall revoke any registration issued under
this section to a person who has pleaded guilty to or been convicted of a
violation of above said regulations, or to a person convicted of two (2)
violations of panhandling registration.
   (g)   Any applicant shall have the right to appeal the denial or revocation
of registration by immediately requesting review by a court of competent
jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2006-066. Passed 9-19-06.)
777.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever is convicted of or pleads guilty to a violation of time,
place, manner, false or misleading solicitation, or causing a minor to
panhandle as mentioned above, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree.
   (b)   Whoever is convicted of or pleads guilty to a violation of
registration for panhandling shall, upon the first offense, be guilty of a
minor misdemeanor.
   (c)   Whoever is convicted of or pleads guilty to a violation of
registration for panhandling within twelve (12) months subsequent to having
been convicted of, or having pled guilty to, a previous violation of
registration for panhandling shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree.
(Ord. 2006-066. Passed 9-19-06.)

CHAPTER 903
Excavations
903.01   Permit required.
903.02   Deposit required before opening.
903.03   Bond required.
903.04   Bond not required.
903.05   Excavations.
903.06   Openings to be refilled.
903.07   Officer may demand exhibit of permit.
903.08   Use of revenue from permits.
903.09   Streets not to be disturbed for three years.
903.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Liability for damage - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
      Digging, excavating and piling earth on streets - see Ohio R.C. 5589.10
      Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.
521.03
903.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, partnership or corporation, including any public utility or its
agents, but excluding the State and the City, shall open up or break into the
streets, avenues, alleys or public ways of the City, or break into or open up
any unpaved portion of a street, avenue, alley or public way in the City for
the purpose of connecting water, gas or heating pipes, or sewers, drains or
ditches until such person, partnership or corporation has obtained permission
in writing to do so from the Service-Safety Director of the City.
   In the event a public utility finds it necessary to make emergency repairs
to its existing facilities during hours when City offices are closed or if such
emergency endangers the life or property of the residents of the City, such
public utility may break open or excavate a public way without obtaining a
permit.
   All openings made as emergency openings shall be reported at the City
offices on the business day next following such excavation or opening and a
permit shall be obtained at that time.
(1979 Code 93.10)
903.02 DEPOSIT REQUIRED BEFORE OPENING.
   No person, partnership or corporation, including any public utility or its
agents, shall break into, open up or disturb the pavement of any paved street,
avenue, alley or public way of the City, until the person, partnership or
corporation has deposited with the Service-Safety Director of the City not less
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or the sum of thirty dollars ($30.00) per
running foot for the total length of the opening or excavation, whichever is
greater, to pay for replacing and repairing the pavement or surface by the
Service-Safety Director.
   No person shall open or disturb a greater area than that authorized by the
permit for which the deposit has been made. Should the above required deposit
exceed the actual cost of the supervision and expense of re-laying and
repairing the street or public way, then the excess shall be refunded. Any
public utility or its agents operating under a franchise with the City, or a
contractor, may, with the consent of the Engineering Department and the
Service-Safety Director, in lieu of the aforesaid deposit for each opening,
make a single deposit at the beginning of each calendar year in the amount of
five thousand dollars ($5,000) or an acceptable performance bond in the amount
of five thousand dollars ($5,000), to be held by the City, and to be used on
determination by the Engineering Department for the replacement of pavement or
the repair of faulty pavement by the public utility with the remaining balance
at the end of each calendar year being refunded to the public utility. This
provision shall not be determined to excuse obtaining a permit as required in
Section
903.01.
(1979 Code 93.11)
903.03 BOND REQUIRED.
   Before any person, partnership or corporation, including a public utility,
is authorized, and before a written permit is granted, to open up or break into
the streets, alleys, avenues or public ways of the City, there shall be
deposited with the clerk of the Service-Safety Director by the person,
partnership or corporation applying for such permit, satisfactory bond in the
sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000). It shall be conditioned to secure and
hold harmless the City against any and all damages arising from the opening or
excavation made in the street or other public ways of the City, and further
conditioned to fill and place in good and safe condition, to the satisfaction
of the Service-Safety Director, all openings and excavations. Such bond shall
not be held for replacing or repairing the pavement. An annual bond may be
given under this provision each year conditioned as above to all openings and
excavations made in the streets or other public ways of the City, by the
principal in such bond during the term of one year from the date.
(Ord. 2001-43. Passed 5-15-01.)
903.04 BOND NOT REQUIRED.
   The provisions of Section
903.03 shall not apply to any person, partnership, or corporation licensed by
the City to make connections with the sewers or drains of the City, or to
persons engaged in making public improvements in the streets or other public
ways in the City under contract with the City.
(1979 Code 93.13)
903.05 EXCAVATIONS.
   Every person, partnership or corporation, including a public utility making
or having made openings or excavations in the streets or public ways of the
City, shall guard the same at all times with sufficient and suitable guard
rails and proper lights for the purpose of warning and protecting persons and
animals traveling on such streets or public ways.
(1979 Code 93.14)
903.06 OPENINGS TO BE REFILLED.
   No excavation or opening made in the streets or other public ways of the
City shall be permitted to remain open for a longer time than is absolutely
necessary to do the work described in the permit granted for such excavation,
and the person, partnership or corporation making such excavation or opening
shall refill the same without delay with such material and in such manner as
the Service-Safety Director shall direct. Such opening or excavation shall be
completely filled to the surface of the pavement, and such backfilling shall be
done within forty-eight hours after the completion of the work required by such
opening or excavation, and shall be done so as to make the traveled surface at
least as good as it was before it was disturbed. Any excavation or opening in
the paved portion of the street made by a public utility shall be repaved at
the cost of the person, partnership or corporation making such excavation, and
shall be replaced in accordance with specific directions from the Service-
Safety Director. Such paving shall be done not less than seven days after the
closing of the opening or excavation. All openings and excavations shall be put
in a condition safe for public travel on such street or public way. Any person,
partnership or corporation which leaves a job site or excavation in an
unfinished condition or in a condition hazardous to the public shall be subject
to the penalty hereinafter provided.
(1979 Code 93.15)
903.07 OFFICER MAY DEMAND EXHIBIT OF PERMIT.
   Any person, partnership or corporation, and the agent of any person,
partnership or corporation, who is engaged in disturbing the pavement of or
breaking into or excavating in the streets or other public ways of the City,
shall on demand exhibit to any officer of the City, employee of the Service-
Safety Director, or any police officer the written permit above provided for.
The neglect or refusal of any person, partnership or corporation to so exhibit
such written permit on demand shall subject such person, partnership or
corporation, or such agent thereof, to the penalties hereinafter provided for.
(1979 Code 93.16)
903.08 USE OF REVENUE FROM PERMITS.
   The sum or sums of money so collected and deposited under the requirements
of Section
903.02 shall be paid into the City Treasury by the Service-Safety Director and
deposited to the credit of a special and separate fund to be used and disbursed
solely for the purpose of paying for the repairing and replacing of pavement
broken into or disturbed for any of the purposes mentioned herein.
(1979 Code 93.17)
903.09 STREETS NOT TO BE DISTURBED FOR THREE YEARS.
   After the improvement of any street or public way by paving or repaving has
been completed, then no permit shall be granted or issued by the Service-Safety
Director to any person, firm or corporation to remove or disturb in any manner
or for any purpose, other than for the purpose of making necessary repairs to
pipes, lines or conduits, for a period of three years from the date of the
completion of the improvement.
(1979 Code 93.24)
903.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree.
CHAPTER 905
Sidewalk Program
905.01    Sidewalks required.
905.02    Sidewalks not required.

905.06    Notification.
905.07    Bonding procedure.
905.08    Responsibilities of City Engineer.
905.09   Deferment of payment of sidewalk assessment program for financial
hardship.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Construction and repair - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
      Sidewalk obstructions - see GEN. OFF.
521.04
      Duty to keep in repair, clean - see GEN. OFF.
521.06
905.01 SIDEWALKS REQUIRED.
   Sidewalks shall be required as follows:
   (a)   On all streets in newly platted subdivisions.
   (b)   On properties where a new primary structure is being constructed.
   (c)   All streets (other than those in newly platted subdivisions) within
the corporate limits of the City, that do not have sidewalks on 100% of the
street frontage shall be designated as either a primary or secondary
thoroughfare. The intent of this chapter and a guiding principle of its
implementation shall be to exempt property owners from having to install
sidewalks whose houses abut quiet residential streets which experience minimal
or modest vehicular traffic that is primarily local in nature by designating
those streets as secondary thoroughfares.
   (d)   All street designations shall be promulgated at a public hearing by a
majority vote of a Street Designation Committee composed of: the Mayor; two
members of Council, one of which shall be the Chairman of the Streets and
Sidewalks Committee, the other to be nominated by the President of Council and
approved by a majority of Council; the Safety-Service Director; the City
Engineer; a citizen nominated by the President of Council and approved by a
majority of Council and a citizen nominated by the Mayor and approved by
Council. With the exception of the Mayor, the City Engineer and the Safety-
Service Director, all of whom shall be permanent members, Street Designation
Committee members shall serve staggered terms as follows, with vacancies to be
filled upon the expiration of that member's term: citizen nominated by the
Mayor, two years; citizen nominated by the President of Council, one year;
member of Council, one year; Chairman of Streets and Sidewalks, two years.
   (e)   Considerations in establishing or changing the designation of a street
(or any section thereof) as a primary or secondary thoroughfare shall be
primarily public safety as it relates to traffic, usage and practical need. In
the event any property owners abutting any street disagree with the designation
of their particular street, said owners may appeal directly to Council which
may, by a three-fourths majority vote, override the decision of the Street
Designation Committee.
   (f)   Streets which shall have been designated as primary thoroughfares
shall be required to have sidewalks installed by the property owners whose
property abuts the subject street pursuant to the provisions outlined in
Sections 905.02 through 905.08, inclusive.
   (g)   Streets which have been designated as a secondary thoroughfare shall
not be required to have sidewalks installed by the property owners whose
property abuts the subject street unless a majority of the property owners of a
particular street on a front footage basis (not just a majority of property
owners, but a majority of front footage owners) petition Council to require the
installation of sidewalks in the same manner and pursuant to the same criteria
established in these Codified Ordinances. If a majority of the owners on a
front footage basis have petitioned Council for the installation of sidewalks,
the provisions outlined in Sections 905.02 through 905.08, inclusive, shall
apply.
   (H)   This chapter repeals all pending orders by the City to install new
sidewalks.
      (Ord. 2002-108. Passed 12-17-02.)
905.02 SIDEWALKS NOT REQUIRED.
   Sidewalks shall not be required as follows by reason of the fact that they
do not constitute thoroughfares:
(Exemptions)
   (a)   Alleys and unplatted streets.
   (b)   On unimproved streets with a right of way of less than thirty feet.
   (c)   Cul-de-sacs with less than six fronting homes.
   (d)   Dead-end streets, excluding corner lots.
      (Init. Ord. Approved by voters 11-5-96.)
   (e)   In all platted and recorded industrial parks where said property is
zoned exclusively for industrial use.
      (Ord. 2000-10. Passed 2-15-00.)
   All matters pertaining to exemptions shall be under the jurisdiction and
authority of Council and its committees.
(Init. Ord. Approved by voters 11-5-96.)
905.03 PROCEDURE FOR REQUESTING VARIANCES.
   An appeal procedure for variances is established as follows:
   (a)   Variances may be granted for the following reasons:
      (1)   Variances for a specified period of time established by the City
Engineer.
         A.   Allowance for settling of sidewalk right of way due to recent
excavation and subsequent filling.
         B.   Evidence of scheduled construction or excavation within the
sidewalk right of way.
   (b)   Upon receipt of notice requiring installation and specified date of
completion, the property owner may file a request for variance. This appeal for
variance must be filed with Council no later than ninety days prior to the
completion date. Council shall retain exclusive authority to grant or rescind
all variances.
      (1)   Location variances.
         A.   Location variances may be granted as needed, provided continual
passage between abutting properties is maintained. Continual passage along
abutting properties should be in a consistent pattern.
      (2)   Indefinite variances.
         A.   Sidewalk installation impracticabilities, as determined by the
City Engineer, whereby existing buildings or mature shade trees preclude
installation of sidewalks at proper location on property.
         B.   Engineering impracticabilities, as determined by the City
Engineer, may provide cause for a variance to be granted until such time as the
problem is eliminated.
   (c)   This chapter rescinds all previously granted variances.
   (d)   All matters pertaining to variances shall be under the jurisdiction
and authority of Council and its committees.
      (Init. Ord. Approved by voters 11-5-96.)
905.04 PRIORITIES FOR SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION.
   Priorities for sidewalk construction on primary thoroughfares throughout the
City are as follows:
   (a)    The following zones are established with the listed schools being the
central point of each sidewalk zone and said priority is established by an
alphabetical listing for primary thoroughfares as follows:
      (1)   Benjamin Franklin
      (2)   Bigelow Hill
      (3)    Blanchard Valley School
      (4)    Central Middle School
      (5)    Chamberlin Hill
      (6)   Donnell Middle School
      (7)    Glenwood Middle School
      (8)    Jacobs
      (9)   Jefferson      
      (10)   Lincoln
      (11)   Northview
      (12)   St. Michael's East
      (13)   St. Michael's West
      (14)    Washington
      (15)   Whittier
      (16)   Wilson Vance
   (b)   Sidewalks shall be installed as soon as practicable, without regard to
the priority areas above, where it has been determined that there is a hazard
to the safety of pedestrian traffic.
   (c)   Proper and existing sidewalks removed at the time of a street
improvement shall be replaced at the expense of the City.
      (Init. Ord. Approved by voters 11-5-96.)
905.05 IMPLEMENTATION OF SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION.
   Implementation of the construction of sidewalks on primary thoroughfares
based on the priority areas established in Section
905.04 is as follows:
   (a)    Starting with the first school on the list in Section
905.04, then with each successive school in alphabetical order, sidewalks are
to be constructed within a zone having a radius of 750 feet centered on each
school. This shall be considered Zone 1 for each school.
   (b)    Once sidewalks have been constructed with the first zone, sidewalks
are to be constructed in alphabetical order by school and in numerical order by
zone with each zone consisting of the radii below centered on each school.
Zone Feet
2    1,250
3    1,700
4    2,100
5    2,450
6    2,750
7    3,000
8    3,500
9    4,000
10   5,000
11   6,000
      If additional zones are required, they are to be created at intervals of
1,000 feet.
   (c)    This procedure will be used until all areas within the corporate
limits of the City are covered as required by this chapter.
   (d)    Properties split by one or more zone boundaries will be required to
install sidewalks on the entire property at one time.
   (e)    All properties annexed after the passage of this chapter must have
sidewalks installed by July 31 of the year following annexation, at the expense
of the property owner. (Ord. 2002-108. Passed 12-17-02.)
905.06 NOTIFICATION.
   Notification shall be as follows:
   (a)   Council will enact a resolution of necessity pursuant to Ohio R.C.
729.02 calling for the installation of sidewalks in the areas designated by the
City Engineer pursuant to the Street Designation Committee and notification to
the affected property owners will be handled in compliance with Ohio R.C.
729.03.
   (b)    The notification shall require the property owner to install
sidewalks at his own expense in accordance with standards established by the
City Engineer within one year from date of notification. This notification will
include procedures to request a variance and the conditions under which a
variance may be granted.
   (c)   If notification of repair or replacement of existing sidewalks is
given to the property owner, the cost of the repair or replacement of said
sidewalk will be at the property owner's expense which is in accordance with
other existing City ordinances.
      (Ord. 1997-93. Passed 8-19-97.)
905.07 BONDING PROCEDURE.
   The bonding procedure for installation of sidewalks in the City shall remain
in effect subject only to the following modifications:
   (a)   Only performance bonds and/or a cash bond will be accepted to assure
compliance with the sidewalk program in the City, and said bonds shall be
approved by the Director of Law.
      (Ord. 2001-43. Passed 5-15-01.)
   (b)   If a performance bond is not acceptable or if the individual,
partnership or corporation is unable to secure a bond, then, and in such event
a cash bond of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per lineal foot of sidewalk to
cover the cost of sidewalk construction will be placed with the City.
      (Ord. 2004-24. Passed 4-6-04.)
   (c)    The City Engineer shall be responsible for and determine all cost
estimates for sidewalk installation in the City.
      (Ord. 2001-43. Passed 5-15-01.)
905.08 RESPONSIBILITIES OF CITY ENGINEER.
   The City Engineer shall have the following responsibilities in the
enforcement of this chapter.
   (a)   Shall determine what sidewalk construction can realistically be
accomplished during any given construction season.
   (b)   Shall prepare the proper notice with the information as required so
that the Council Clerk may cause said notice to be served on the affected
property owners pursuant to Ohio R.C. 729.03.
   (c)   Shall supervise both survey and construction work to insure that the
sidewalks are installed properly and pursuant to the proper plans and
specifications as established by the City Engineer's office.
   (d)   Shall insure that sidewalks are installed in compliance with this
chapter in regard to City-owned property.
   (e)   Shall insure that all bonding requirements as established herein and
as currently existing in these Codified Ordinances are strictly enforced.
   (f)   Shall provide guidance with respect to request for variances.
   (g)   Shall review all variances two years following the year granted and
each succeeding two years until sidewalks are installed.
      (Init. Ord. Approved by voters 11-5-96.)
905.09 DEFERMENT OF PAYMENT OF SIDEWALK ASSESSMENT PROGRAM FOR FINANCIAL
HARDSHIP.
   Within thirty (30) days after an invoice is sent from the City to a property
owner for the payment of construction and/or repair of a sidewalk on said
owner’s property, the owner(s) of the property against which assessments are to
be levied, pursuant to Ohio Revised Code 729.01 et seq., may apply to the
legislative authority of a municipal corporation for a deferment of payment of
the assessment on the grounds that timely payment will impose financial
hardship upon said individual(s). Upon notification to the City Administration,
within said thirty (30) day period aforementioned, that a request for hardship
determination has been filed, the City shall request the previous two (2) years
of federal tax returns or other proof of financial hardship to be submitted to
the City Income Tax Office within ten (10) days after said request has been
made by the City. The guidelines to be followed for hardship shall be the
latest Poverty Guidelines published by the Federal Government which are
currently as follows:
# in Household 100%   150%   200%
1              9,310  13,965 19,620
2              12,490 18,735 24,980
3              15,670 23,505 31,340
4              18,850 28,275 37,700
5              22,210 33,045 44,060
6              25,210 37,815 50,420
7              28,390 42,585 56,780
8              31,570 47,355 63,140
 
and shall use the 150% or less federal guidelines as set forth herein as the
basis for payment as follows:
   (a)   If the applicant does not qualify said sidewalk repair or construction
will be paid over two (2) years (4 payments).
   (b)   If the applicant qualifies for the 150% poverty level as set forth
herein, they shall have a four (4) year payment plan (8 payments).
   (c)   If the poverty guideline of 100% or less is met, a total deferment
shall be granted and it shall become a lien on said property subject to the
sidewalk assessment and said assessment lien shall not be payable until the
earliest of the following:
      (1)   At such time as the property is either sold or transferred by the
applicant;
      (2)   At such time as the property becomes subject to Ohio estate taxes
under Ohio R.C. Chapter 5731;
      (3)   In the event of the death of the applicant(s).
         (Ord. 2004-49. Passed 6-15-04.)
CHAPTER 906
Sidewalk Obstructions and Maintenance
906.01   Sidewalk obstructions; damage or injury.
906.02   Duty to keep sidewalks in repair and clean.
906.03   Sidewalk cafes.
CROSS REFERENCES
            Driving on sidewalks - see TRAF.
 331.37
            Parking on sidewalks - see TRAF.
351.03
906.01 SIDEWALK OBSTRUCTIONS; DAMAGE OR INJURY.
   (a)   No person shall place or knowingly drop upon any part of a sidewalk,
playground or other public place any tacks, bottles, wire, glass, nails or
other articles which may damage property of another or injure any person or
animal traveling along or upon such sidewalk or playground.
   (b)   No person shall walk on, or allow any animal upon, or injure or deface
in any way, any soft or newly laid sidewalk pavement.
   (c)   No person shall place or set for exhibition any goods, wares or
merchandise on any of the sidewalks of the City, or obstruct the free public
use of the street, alley, sidewalk or public place in front of any place of
business, store or building, except within three feet of and directly in front
of any such store or building where there is a sidewalk constructed from the
property line to the curb. No goods, wares or merchandise shall be allowed to
remain on any sidewalk between the curb and within three feet of the store or
building, except while receiving or delivering such goods, wares or
merchandise. For such purposes that part of the sidewalk next to the curb line
not exceeding four feet in width and only in front of such store or building
may be so used for the space of thirty minutes at any time, but no longer.
   (d)   No person shall unload upon, or transport any heavy merchandise,
goods, material or equipment over or across any sidewalk or curb without first
placing some sufficient protection over the pavement to protect against damage
or injury. The affected area shall be rendered safe and free from danger.
   (e)   No person shall allow any cellar or trap door, coal chute or elevator
or lift opening in any sidewalk to remain open without providing suitable
safeguards to protect and warn pedestrian traffic of the dangerous condition.
   (f)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 1998-77. Passed 9-15-98.)
906.02 DUTY TO KEEP SIDEWALKS IN REPAIR AND CLEAN.
   (a)   The owners or occupants of abutting lots and land in the City shall
keep the sidewalk in front of and along their respective lots in good repair
and free from filth, mud or any nuisance. The owners or occupants shall remove
all snow, ice and dirt from the sidewalk along or in front of their respective
property within twelve hours after any snowfall or within two hours after being
notified by the Service-Safety Director to remove the same.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to report all violations
of this section to the Service-Safety Director.
(1979 Code 93.46)
   (c)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 1998-77. Passed 9-15-98.)
906.03 SIDEWALK CAFES.
   (a)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, Sidewalk Cafés
may be permitted in the City of Findlay in accordance with the rules and
regulations as promulgated by the Safety Director and as hereinafter amended
from time to time.
   (b)   No person or entity shall operate a Sidewalk Café without first
obtaining a valid permit from the Safety Director and no person or entity shall
operate said Sidewalk Café in violation of any rule or regulation promulgated
by the Safety Director of the City of Findlay. Any such violation may result in
revocation of said Sidewalk Café permit.
(Ord. 2012-057. Passed 8-21-12.)
CHAPTER 907
Sidewalk Repair and Construction
907.01   Inspection and notice.
907.02   Supervision and construction.
